Speech notes on amendments to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985.

I intend to move, on behalf of the Government, amendments that have been circulated to honourable senators. I do so in order to accommodate most of the concerns expressed by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in its report on the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985, and also to effect a number of amendments of a minor technical nature.

As honourable senators will know, on 8 May 1985, the Senate agreed to the motion of Senator Coates, the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, that this Bill be referred to that committee for inquiry and report. The Committee had been conducting an inquiry into the operations of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust.

Senator Coates tabled the Standing Committee's report on the Bill on 15 May 1985. The Government was pleased to note that the Committee approved generally of the provisions of the Bill which are aimed primarily at both giving the trust the freedom and flexibiliy to operate in the best interests of contributors to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and enhancing the accountability of the Trust.

The Committee made five recommendations in its report. Four of these propose the insertion of additional provisions in the Bill. The fifth recommends that the Government obtain the advice of the Attorney-General on the matter of the legal liability of members of the trust and trust staff. I will return to this recommendation shortly.

As Senator Coates remarked when tabling the Standing Committee's report, the matters recommended for inclusion in the Bill would undoubtedly happen in practice anyway. Nevertheless, the Government has agreed to accept the thrust of recommendations 1, 2 and 4, which in major part go to further enhancing the accountability of the trust to the Parliament and to contributors.
The Government does not, however, accept the Committee's recommendation 3.

Recommendation 3 of the Standing Committee seeks to provide that one or the other of the principal member of the trust or the part-time Government nominee member is to have special qualifications in investment matters.

The proposed structure of the enlarged Trust, and the duties and responsibilities imposed upon it under the legislation, indicate the need for the trust to have members with broad qualifications, not necessarily related solely to investment. These duties and responsibilities involve not only the investment of the superannuation fund, but also the exercise of prudential controls, determination of policy and liaision with relevant industrial organisations as well as the staffing, control and oversight of the office of the Trust.
In short, management of the superannuation fund goes well beyond investment of the fund.

I have already drawn the attention of honourable senators to Senator Coates's remark that the matters recommended for inclusion in the Bill by the Standing Committee would undoubtedly happen in practice anyway. The process of selection of Trust members, whether conducted to meet the requirements of the Minister or relevant industrial organisations in concert with the ACTU, will certainly have due regard to financial and investment expertise among the many qualities required of members of the Trust. The legislative specification of a requirement for such expertise would not only be redundant but would focus concern on only one aspect of the necessary qualifications, whether required of the principal member or the part-time Government nominee, perhaps to the detriment of other, equally important concerns.
The amendments accepted by the Government are intended to:
Require the ACTU to nominate persons for appointment to the Trust only from those persons whose names have been submitted to the ACTU by relevant industrial organisations:
Require a copy of any interim report made by the Trust, together with interim financial statements, to be tabled in the Parliament; and

Ensure that the Trusts's Annual Report and any interim report will include particulars of any statement of Government policy provided by the Minister to the Trust (by way of the principal member) during the year, the consideration given by the trust to the policy and the action, if any, taken.

While, for drafting reasons, the precise wording and positioning in the Bill of the additional provisions differ somewhat from the recommendations of the Standing Committee, the substance of the recommendations is retained.

The fifth recommendation of the Standing Committee is to the effect that the Government immediately seek the current opinion of the Attorney-General on the matter of the legal liability of Trust members and Trust staff and introduce an appropriate amendment to the Act defining that liability.

Contrary to the impression that might have been gained by the Standing Committee, the Government has not put aside the matter of legal liability which was first raised in the Monaghan Report and later canvassed in the joint working party report, both of which have been tabled in the Parliament.

Liability, however raises a number of issues of considerable legal complexity. Resolution of these issues is being pursued as expeditiously as possible so that consideration can be given to the matter and, if necessary, appropriate provisions included in the Superannuation Act 1976 when next it is amended

The opportunity is now being taken to also move amendments that are consequential on the proclamation on 21 July 1985 of the date of the commencment of certain sections of the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984.

Before moving the proposed amendments, however, I wish to refer briefly to the June 1985 report from the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust which was tabled by Senator Coates on 21 August 1985. This report is the culmination of the Standing Committee's exhaustive and thorough examination of the affairs, practices and administration of the Trust.

The report deals with, among other things, various reports of the Auditor-General on the Trust's annual reports and financial statements, including the more recent annual report for 1983/84. While the Standing Committee is concerned with progress made in implementing remedial measures in respect of the Trust's accounting and financial management systems, it acknowledges that the new provisions proposed in the Bill should enable the Trust to employ adequate staff with the required skills to oversee properly the accounting and management systems.

On 31 July 1985, before the Standing Committee's report became available, I wrote to the Trust asking that it provide to me, and to the Auditor-General, comprehensive details, including the proposed timetable, of plans for the rehabilitation of the systems and procedures. I asked also that quarterly progress reports be provided by the Trust until such time as the Auditor-General is satisfied that the procedures are adequate.

The Standing Committee's report draws to attention a total of 28 findings and recommendations that either relate specifically to the Trust or have general application to statutory authorities. I propose, at a later date, to make a further response to the Senate on this report.

For the present, I would draw honourable senators' attention to Senator Coates's statement when tabling the report, that the Standing Committee believes the Bill satisfactorily provides for much needed changes to the administration of the Trust. The Standing Committee has not recommended any further changes to the Bill.
I therefore now ask that the amendments proposed by the Government be accepted by the committee.

debate.title:
STUDENT ASSISTANCE (LOANS GUARANTEE AND SUBSIDY) REPEAL BILL 1985
STUDENT ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1985

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 11 September, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating cognately the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Repeal Bill 1985 and the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1985. The Opposition does not oppose the Student Assistance Amendment Bill which seeks to make some minor changes to restructure certain student assistance review tribunals. To the extent that the Bill puts in place certain administrative arrangements of government, we do not question it and we accept what the Government is doing. The Opposition, however, has a strong opposition to and will oppose the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Repeal Bill. It is to this Bill that I will address my remarks.

speech.para: This measure is a benefit deprivation measure. It seeks to remove from the tertiary students of Australia a benefit potentially available to them. It is a matter of regret-in fact, it is an indictment of the Hawke Labor Government-that during its time in office it has failed to implement a student loans scheme when legislation existed to put that scheme into place. It is an indictment of Mr Hawke, of his Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and of his Government that the Government now seeks to repeal the enabling legislation which would make a loans scheme possible. If successful, this repeal will make it impossible for students to avail themselves of the benefits of student loans should any government, present or future, wish to use the existing legislation. Let us be quite clear that it is students from needy backgrounds, disadvantaged students, who would want to use loans but who will not now be able to use them and who will be disadvantaged. This is another example of the Hawke Government removing a potential benefit and seeking to make life more difficult for needy or disadvantaged students.

The loans scheme, which I introduced as Minister for Education in 1982, would have provided an additional source of support for disadvantaged students. It would have provided extra money for students who needed it. It would not have been incumbent upon any student to avail himself or herself of this scheme. However, it would have been possible for any student who wanted so to do to seek a loan. These loans would have been available to students already in receipt of allowances or able to satisfy a means test. The loans were targeted to needy students. What could be wrong with that? The loans were to be made available at concessional rates.

This is merely an extra benefit, which tertiary students could have used and to which they could have turned, which was put in place by the Fraser Government and which this Government has seen fit not to implement. In fact it has put aside the many applications received for loans in March 1983. The loans would have been taken out only by those who wanted them, but, thanks to the Labor Government, students will no longer have that option. As I say, the measure is a benefit deprivation measure, yet another betrayal of Australia's tertiary students by this Government with its miserable record in the areas of student support and tertiary education.

The loans were to be provided at advantageous rates. The legislation which we are asked to repeal now sought only to make available to students loans at concessional interest rates, at better interest rates than they could get on the market. In this day, with this high interest Government and with the country facing the highest interest rates historically for generations, our tertiary students would have benefited from receiving subsidised interest rates for loans which they might have wanted to take out. The Bill which Labor now seeks to repeal provided for a two-year holiday on repayments by students receiving the loans. It provided for needy students to take out loans to improve their chances of completing, and succeeding in, their chosen field of study. The continued existence of the loans scheme would help students. It would not turn away any student from tertiary education, nor would it reduce the opportunities for any student. It is an extra benefit which Labor wants to remove.

Labor must explain to us where the social advantage lies-the benefit to the country or to any student-by taking from students an existing benefit. Of course, Labor has been very big in the past few months about taking away benefits. Ask any large family what it has meant to them to lose the payment of the family allowance for their older student children. Ask them what it has meant to see the value of the tertiary education assistance scheme drop further behind the unemployment benefit. Here we have the removal of what would have been another option for disadvantaged students whose need is greatest and who face the greatest obstacles in making their way through tertiary education.

It is worth while to examine the history of the passage of this legislation. When it was passed it was opposed by the Australian Democrats. They advanced their reasons for voting against it, which I think were incorrect, but that is all right. The Bill was passed in 1982 only because it had the support not only of the then Government, the Liberal and National parties, but also of the Australian Labor Party. What did Labor people say when we tried to put this extra benefit in place? In speaking for the then Opposition in this debate, Senator Button said:
However, as I said, the Opposition--
that was the Labor Party--
does not oppose the legislation. We believe it will provide some benefit to some students and to that extent it is supported.

If Senator Button had that view in 1982, why have Labor senators changed their view in 1985? Senator Button was absolutely correct; this loans scheme would have provided some benefit to some students. He was quite correct that for that reason Labor was right to support the measure. When in opposition, Labor admitted that some needy students would benefit from this legislation and no student would be disadvantaged. So why does it not continue this legislation to allow students the extra option? What ideological barrier has emerged since Labor came to government which has prevented it from providing this extra benefit which might help some students in need? Why repeal the Students Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Act now? No cogent or coherent reasons have been given. There is no coherent reason for repealing this legislation, except blind ideological prejudice.

Not only did Labor vote for the scheme and speak in support of it when it was introduced but also as honourable senators may remember, the question of student loans did not pass straight through this chamber. It was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, chaired at that time by my colleague Senator Baden Teague.

talk.start.para: —A good committee.

—A very good committee. The Committee comprised Senator Baden Teague as Chairman and some Labor senators, including former Senator Jean Hearn and Senators Giles and Robert Ray. I have looked at the report of that Committee and I can find nothing in it which raises any objection to the concept of loans. I can find nothing by way of minority report which seeks to have the Senate consider an alternative view. In fact, the recommendations of that Committee, when it reflected upon the provisions of this Bill, were that it was a good and adequate measure which should be supported. Not only did Senator Button support it on behalf of the Labor Party, but also Labor senators on the Committee, when asked to examine the legislation, reported favourably that it was good, benefit-conferring legislation. We cannot understand why the Labor Party now wants to remove it.

speech.para: I mentioned a few moments ago that Labor has a sorry record in terms of its support for tertiary students. It is worth looking at Senator Button's speech on the 1982 Bill to see some of the things for which he criticised the then Government. Senator Button complained about the gap between the TEAS benefit paid to students and the level of unemployment benefit. Senator Button said:

Following the increases in TEAS in the recent Budget, the TEAS benefit is still at least $5 per week less than the unemployment benefit. What is the incentive in financial terms to embark upon tertiary education when there are very limited assurances about future employment as a result and when the unemployment benefit is pitched at a higher rate?

A very interesting comment by Senator Button. Let us examine the situation since this Government took office in relation to the gap between the TEAS benefit and the unemployment benefit, which so concerned Senator Button in 1982. We know what this Government said about TEAS before it came to office, but what has it done? In its first Budget it increased the education disincentive gap between TEAS and the unemployment benefit from the $5 which I had bequeathed it as Minister, to which Senator Button had referred, to $11. In its first Budget it more than doubled the gap. In the Government's next Budget it increased the gap to $12.30; not for 16 or 17-year old students, but for students 18 years old or over. In its recent third Budget the gap was further increased to $14.72 for students aged between 18 and 20 years and $17.97 for students aged over 20 years. The Fraser Government in the 1982 Budget, when I was Minister for Education, increased the value of the TEAS benefit by 20 per cent. The first three Labor Budgets have seen an increase only marginally greater than that. The gap between TEAS and the unemployment benefit has widened considerably, in spite of Senator Button's rhetoric and the quite explicit promises by Labor to Australia's student population made before the election.

So much for Labor's commitment to provide adequate student assistance. There is all the more reason, in view of this sorry history, to have available student loans as an extra option, with compulsion upon no one to use them, but available to those who might want to take advantage of such a loans scheme.

talk.start.para: —Before the sitting was suspended I was setting out the reasons for our opposition to this Bill which seeks to repeal the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Act 1982. I pointed out that that Act provides a benefit and that this Bill seeks to take that benefit away. I pointed out that the Labor Party in opposition had supported this Act. Senator Button, on behalf of the then Opposition, spoke in support of it. The legislation had been examined and scrutinised by a Senate standing committee which had approved it and reported favourably. I pointed out that the Act provided access to a benefit which would help needy students under advantageous conditions. I asked the question then: `What kind of social benefit, what kind of social goal, lies behind the desire of the Government to remove this benefit, to remove access to loans and to put forward this repeal Bill?' The Government has indicated no benefit to students and, as I pointed out before the sitting was suspended, the record of the Labor Party in government has been to make students worse off rather that better off.

speech.para: I remind the Senate again of one of the points made by Senator Button in 1982 when he was speaking for the Labor Party on the Bill to establish the loans scheme. He made it clear that he had a concern about the gap between TEAS and the unemployment benefit. I have been able to demonstrate that that gap is now worse. It has got much worse with Labor in government than it was when Senator Button made his concern known. So much for Labor's commitment, its solemn promise before the election to close the gap between TEAS and the unemployment benefit. Like so many other Labor promises, it was not worth a crumpet. It was not honoured and it shows no prospect of being honoured. It is one of the many promises that Labor made to students which has now gone by the board. That happened as soon as it was snouts in the trough and Labor was in power. So much for the commitment to provide adequate student assistance. It has not come to pass. That gives us all the more reason for wanting to keep in place this scheme which provides access to some supplementary form of benefits.

The Labor Party has an appalling record of broken promises and downright negligence in its handling of student assistance. It was Labor that complained that the gap between TEAS and the unemployment benefit was a disincentive to people seeking further education. If it was a disincentive in 1982, why is it not equally a disincentive in 1985? Why are Labor's complaints of 1982 Labor's practice of 1985? Why has Labor tripled the size of the gap for some students? In its first three Budgets, Labor's increase in TEAS has not been sufficient to keep up with the increase in unemployment benefit and students are now worse off vis-a-vis unemployment beneficiaries than they were when Senator Button, on behalf of the Labor Party, made his quite telling criticism in 1982. The point at issue are the widening of the education disincentive gap, Labor's failure to increase TEAS adequately and Senator Button's admission that the loan scheme would do some good for some students. Surely that was the crux of it-the scheme would do some good for some students and it would certainly do no harm. Senator Button's own words are strong reasons for retaining and activating the student loans scheme. There is no coherent reason not to have it in place and operating except blind ideological prejudice.

This scheme provides extra capacity for poor students; it puts more power in the hands of the consumers of education, compared with the providers and controllers. Perhaps that is one reason why the scheme is out of favour with the Labor Party, which is committed to planning, to holding power centrally and to not letting consumers near it. The Government must say why it wants to repeal with scheme and it must say what social goals it is pursuing. There is none except to take away benefits-to deny benefits which would otherwise be available-and there is no useful social goal that will be achieved by this repeal Bill.

Fees abolition alone, introduced by Labor in 1974, has not been enough to change the social mix in higher education. The loans scheme, now the subject of a repeal Bill by Labor, could have been one measure which would have helped those of limited means to get access to higher education. Surely that would have been to the benefit of students and education generally. For the reasons I have set out, for the very reasons that Senator Button set out in 1982 when speaking to the legislation, the Opposition believes that this scheme should remain and we will oppose the abolition Bill because we think it serves no one's interests, least of all those of students and those of education.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: —We are debating cognately tonight two tertiary students' measures-the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1985 and the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Repeal Bill 1985. The Australian Democrats will support both those measures. We shall certainly support the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Repeal Bill because, as Senator Peter Baume said in his speech, we opposed the establishment of the loans scheme in the first place. As everybody knows, this scheme was introduced by the Liberal Government in 1982 when Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister and there was some suspicion at the time that the Bill was proposed as a way of phasing out the tertiary education assistance scheme or at least that it had that intention. In any event, the Act was passed to provide the structure for government guarantees to the banks which were to provide the loan moneys. We opposed that scheme for a number of reasons, the main one being that it would not help needy students to get a tertiary education because the sorts of people who would need to borrow money from a bank in order to pursue an academic career-that is, people on low incomes, female students and students from large and migrant families-were the least likely people to have been brought up in the sort of atmosphere where borrowing money for educational purposes was regarded as a valid reason for borrowing money at all. Most of the categories of people whom I have just mentioned are not those to whom borrowing comes naturally. It is far more useful to someone on a middle to high income who wants to get through a three, four or five-year course to borrow money than it is for someone on a low income or someone who is doing part time academic work, as many women must do. For a start, those people are not at all sure about their capacity to repay; many of them are doing studies in an area in which they are not assured of a job afterwards. They are simply doing a tertiary course because they have a belief in the value of tertiary education which, sadly, is not held by large numbers of Australians.

speech.para: Senator Peter Baume was quite right when he commented adversely on what he saw, and what I see, as the Australian Labor Party's poor commitment to tertiary education and, I would suggest, to education generally since it came to office. Senator Baume mentioned the fact that TEAS allowances are still lower than the unemployment benefit, albeit that the gap has narrowed somewhat-and not before time.

talk.start.para: —It has widened, actually.

—All right, but TEAS has been increased. In real terms things are no better, but TEAS has been increased. We have always argued that it seems ludicrous that people should be paid so much to do nothing essentially or to look for some kind of not very academic work when those who are attempting to improve their education and use their talents to the full in order, presumably, to put them to use for the community's benefit are paid such a pittance. As Senator Baume mentioned, the Government has also made it much more difficult to get things such as the family allowance for full time students over the age of 18, and that in itself, especially for large families, is not conducive to encouraging people to go on to higher education.

speech.para: Technical and further education funding was cut in real terms in the last Budget. Research and development funding in Australia has never been good. Compared with other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries we have a particularly appalling commitment in the funds we provide for it. That extends to the private sector, which is equally as loth to put money into research and development areas, particularly in the pure academic sense, presumably because it still takes the school of hard knocks argument or hopes that it will acquire the necessary research and development expertise second hand from overseas. Notwithstanding that, I think it is important to note that in certain areas Australia does lead the world in technological advances, and solar heating is one example. Ironically, the Government is about to slap a 20 per cent sales tax on that area, which again does not indicate any commitment to the technological expertise and potential that our scientists have.

There has been more talk of the need to introduce tertiary fees, something which the previous Government attempted but on which it was defeated. I hope that this also is not brought forward. It would be a total disincentive to a large part of our community in its attempt to get academic education. It may work in America, where the population is so large, but it is not going to help in a country the size of Australia with its population and geographical position. Unless we particularly want to be educationally and technologically isolated we will have to accept that education to tertiary level as well ought to be a right and not a privilege for a fairly wealthy elite.

I am as concerned at what appears to be the Liberal Party's attitude to tertiary education as I am at the Australian Labor Party's. If Mr Peter Shack is to be believed, we are going to turn education into some kind of industry which will be expected to do things such as compete in the market place. He talks about the solution to our problems in education lying in exposing education to market forces in this area, whatever they may be. He refers to education as an industry. If he is to be believed, the Opposition is firmly committed to a user pays education system which must inevitably lead to limiting access, particularly to the longer degree courses such as dentistry, architecture, engineering, medicine and so on, to an elite-

talk.start.para: —He hasn't said that.
—He was quoted in the Australian on 2 October this year as addressing the Melbourne branch of the Liberal Party recently on deregulating education. The newspaper states:

speech.para: . . . the Australian education system was one of the most highly protected and regulated systems, and indeed industries, in Australia. As such it exhibited all the worst features of monopoly controlled, protected and regulated industries.
He went on to say:
I am convinced that the solution lies with exposing the system to market forces by returning to the consumers of educational services some bargaining power.

He said that academics would be told: `Wake up! You can't afford to behave like self-satisfied public servants anymore.' They would have to `lift their game and learn to compete in the market place for the scarce resource-
namely, taxpayers' money-
. . . which will be attached to the student patrons they manage to attract'.

That overlooks entirely the fact that unless we have a free and readily accessible education system at the tertiary level, we are going to limit access to education to those who can pay. If Senator Baume is concerned about the fact that I may well be misinterpreting Liberal Party policy on tertiary education, I can ask him only to look at the Fraser Government's attempt to reintroduce tertiary fees. So we will certainly be happy to support the repeal of the student loans scheme.

The second Bill we are debating tonight, the Student Assistance Amendment Bill, is relatively uncontroversial. It is almost entirely restricted to administrative reforms relating to the Student Assistance Review Tribunals. Under this amendment Bill the present tribunals are to be replaced by a single tribunal panel with any hearing consisting of two panel members plus a convener. It does what the second reading speech calls `clarifying'. It clarifies the fact that the contents of documents presented at tribunal hearings will not be disclosed to students if the documents are income tax documents or if they refer to the income of third parties, such as their parents. The second reading speech said:

An amendment was also proposed in relation to the protection of Australian Taxation Office and other confidential documents made available to the SART. The amendment will insert a new provision, proposed section 29B, which will substantially repeal the existing provisions at present contained in section 25(2), with the following modifications: It will be clarified that documents are to be protected during a SART hearing as well as at the pre-hearing stage; oral disclosure of a document's contents will be prohibited where disclosure of the document itself is prohibited; the restriction on the disclosure of a document dealing with a person's affairs will not generally apply if the person agrees to the disclosure.

I would like some clarification from the Minister on that to determine the extent to which this is likely to affect a student's ability or otherwise to present his or her case. I am not perfectly clear just what the amendment is likely to do as far as a student's ability to argue a case before the Tribunal is concerned.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister here to answer you?
—Senator Grimes is. I am sure he is perfectly competent to answer a question with a little help from some friends on the other side.
—No, I don't even need that.

—He does not even need that. That is fine. We accept what the Minister says in the second reading speech; namely, that there is a problem in balancing privacy with open access to documents. Nevertheless, students who are presenting an appeal before the Tribunal ought to be given access to as many documents as possible. I suggest that should also apply to things such as briefing notes, which are provided to the Tribunal by the Department of Education. Since apparently the Tribunal claims not to be bound by precedent, the briefing notes are used as guidelines for the decision that it makes in each case. I wonder whether any consideration has been given to making those briefing notes available to students appearing before the Tribunal. If it has not, perhaps that could be taken on board, since it would presumably give them some assistance. Fighting an appeal without knowing what the rules are and being aware that precedents are apparently not taken into account makes life a little more difficult than it need be.

speech.para: The legislation also provides for some fairly inoffensive delegation of ministerial powers to public servants. Whilst that is to be deplored if it goes too far, in this case it seems to be reasonably innocuous. The Bill also extends the time within which prosecutions for offences under the Crimes Act must be commenced-from within one year of the offence being committed to two. The amendment will not apply to offences committed before the legislation comes into force but it will obviously apply to students who subsequently run into difficulties. I would like the Minister to justify that increase. I have no objections to it. I think it is fair enough that people have that extra time. But can the Minister tell us whether it was caused by some inefficiency in the Department? Is the Department understaffed? Is it some gesture of good will to students? Why has the need been found to extend the time within which prosecutions for offences under the Act can be commenced? Is it just good will towards the Department?

There are a couple of other comments that I would like to make with regard not to what the legislation does but to what it does not do. I have already mentioned the first of those, that is, access to briefing notes. The second relates to the time necessary to hear appeals. In Victoria, and some other States, I understand that it frequently takes up to eight months before some students appeals are heard by the Tribunal. This means that even if the appeals are successful, they have had to virtually finance themselves for the entire academic year while they wait for their appeals to be heard. That seems somewhat excessive, and I would like to know whether the Government is taking any steps at all, either through legislation or simply by increasing staffing, to cut that time back, particularly in Victoria, from eight months. It definitely does not work in the interests of students. It must be a strain on them and act as a disincentive to any academic progress they are likely to make that year. It is the sort of stress that a student does not need to have applied in addition to the usual stresses that apply when going for a degree. So the Democrats will be supporting both pieces of legislation. If the Minister can come up with some answers to the questions I have asked, I would appreciate it.

speech.speaker: Zakharov Sen A.O.

talk.start.para: —We are debating cognately the Student Assistance Amendment Bill and the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Repeal Bill. I would like to deal briefly, first, with the one that is perhaps less controversial, and that is the Student Assistance Amendment Bill. This Bill affects the tertiary education assistance scheme and the post-graduate award scheme. I hope that the question of appeals for secondary students can also be addressed soon, rather than waiting until the schemes have merged in a couple of years time. These amendments refer to appeal procedures and structures to implement the results of a review which was undertaken last year. They provide for simplication of the appeal structure, based on the structure of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Some of the important provisions are that the Bill will enable ministerial responsibility to be delegated to senior people, thereby saving valuable time when the Minister is unavailable. For example, I believe in times of heavy work load, sometimes junior officers, and even at times temporary officers, have to be appointed as assessors, particularly for the tertiary education assistance scheme.

speech.para: The Bill extends the time limit for prosecution to two years from what is in effect one year at present. It has proved very difficult to complete the whole process leading to a prosecution in one year, and I believe it is important that people who are deliberately abusing the scheme-and we all know that that happens-for example, by falsifying tax figures, should be prosecuted, thus ensuring that the money available goes to those in greatest need. On the other hand, it is important to point out in this context-knowing how the rumour mills grind-that any decision to prosecute takes into account such circumstances as the student's age and the gravity of the offence. Another important provision of the Bill clarifies the situation if a student fails to receive notice of a hearing by allowing the hearing to be reheard.

I come now to the more controversial Bill, which I understand the Opposition is opposing-understandably, I guess, because it repeals its own legislation. The legislation which the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Repeal Bill repeals was passed by the Fraser Government late in 1982. Since that Government lost office early in 1983, it was never implemented. The present Government made a commitment to repeal the Act during the election campaign in 1983, and the intention to repeal was announced in the very early days of the present Government. Indeed, its repeal was foreshadowed by Senator Button during debate on the Bill in 1982, when he said:
I want to make it quite clear that, in the context of more adequate and better directed student assistance, an ALP government would abandon this scheme and repeal the legislation.

That is exactly what is happening now. The only reason that this repeal has taken so long was that it had low priority since the Act was actually inoperative. The scheme was never fully implemented and, indeed, the regulations necessary for implementation had not been made. Agreements with banks had not been finalised; I will return later to the attitude of the banks. It is interesting to note that although leaflets and forms had been circulated before Parliament was dissolved for the election, there was no loud protest when the scheme did not proceed. The 1982 Bill was not finally opposed by the then Opposition because-and I think this is important-in the context of the time, following the razor gang cuts to education funds, it was seen to be of benefit to some students.

talk.start.para: —It still is.
—I do not think the honourable senator would find that the students agree with him. As Senator Button said in debate:

speech.para: The Opposition concedes that it may be of benefit to some students at the margin . . . to some students in middle-income groups from relatively well-off socio-economic backgrounds.

The legislation we are now repealing was vigorously opposed by the majority of students and student organisations in a campaign which had very strong and broad support at the grass roots. It was also widely opposed by other groups, such as the Australian Council of Trade Unions and many tertiary academic staff and administrators.

talk.start.para: —A group of vested interests, eh?
—The honourable senator is imputing evil motives where none may lie.
—Just stating fact.

—It may be the honourable senator's idea of fact. The opposition to the Bill was on a number of grounds: Grounds of equity and also fear of possible further action-I will return to that-but also on its viability; the banks, on which the success of the scheme depended, were less than enthusiastic; overseas experience in the United States and in Europe, where similar schemes had taught the banks to be cautious; and experience of difficulty in tracing students after graduation who did not want to be traced, for example. So the Australian banks wanted to reserve the right to give loans only to those they considered credit worthy, which might well have been on much tougher criteria than those in the legislation. I think it is likely that if this stance had finally prevailed, if commercial considerations had won out, there would have been a repetition of the United States experience, where students studying for the well-paid professions, male students mainly who might be expected to have an uninterrupted earning capacity and students young enough to be able to pay back the loans over a period, would be the preferred loan recipients. What then would be the chances for the mature age student, the woman of child bearing age, the student embarking on a course such as humanities, where employment is less certain? The overseas experience was that poorer students did not take out loans, fearing they could not pay them back and having no well-heeled relatives as a back-up.

speech.para: This leads me further into the equity question. Loans as a basic means of financing study, as distinct from the emergency loans to which I will refer later, are intrinsically inequitable and can have a deleterious social effect. They are inequitable, because, as I referred to before, they give an advantage to those who are already advantaged-those who have reason to believe that they are assured of well-paid work after graduation, and those who feel they can take out a loan because if they cannot pay it back, they have families who could help. But the social effects of financing study in this way can also be harmful. A graduate who completes his or her course with a large debt, even given a breathing space after graduation, which was allowed for in the legislation, is likely to feel constrained to seek, fairly immediately an income sufficient to pay back the loan. They might otherwise benefit, and the community might also benefit, from seeking overseas experience, perhaps low paid or voluntary work on an aid project, or they may prefer to work for a low wage in a job of high community value, such as a project worker with a self-help group, or the co-ordinator of, say a volunteer scheme for the homeless.

In addition, many new graduates do not automatically find immediate jobs. This is true in a number of career areas and is not always predictable. When students start out on a course, there may be lots of job opportunities, but by the time they finish those courses, between three and five years later, those opportunities may have disappeared. They may not be able to find any sort of work for some time. It is not always an advantage to be a graduate, especially if one is over 21, if one is applying for semi-skilled or unskilled work. To be in debt, even if the debt is deferred, as well as being unemployed is not a good start to independent adulthood.

But the main fear in the minds of students, then as now, was that any loan scheme which provided long term income support could be the precursor to an attack on TEAS or even a precursor to the reintroduction of tertiary fees. Since loans were already available to many students on some campuses and through some credit unions, and at least one bank that I know of, a further loan scheme on the scale anticipated was thus seen as being very likely to be the thin end of such a wedge. To quote Senator Button again, in 1982 he said:
Maybe this Budget represents the last increase in TEAS by this-
that is, the Fraser-
Government if this loans scheme is, in fact, a sort of foot-in-the-door job.

If a substantial loan scheme is put in place it is easier, at least in the perception of the general public, to downgrade other financial assistance. Few people outside students and their families have a real understanding of the costs of study on top of the costs of basic living expenses. Unfortunatley, as a spectator sport student bashing is even easier than union bashing.

To return to the question of emergency loans which I referred to earlier, the present Government has provided funds to all tertiary institutions to enable them to give emergency loans or, in some cases, grants to students in need. These funds are in the hands of the institution, with student representation on the committees which allocate the money.

talk.start.para: —How much and when?
—I have not the details with me. It is already operating.
—It is not true; only 10 years ago, 1973 was the date.

—No, it is operating now. It is in the hands of those best able to assess needs. In addition, of course, in each of the last three Budgets TEAS allowances have been increased, as has the marginal adjusted family income limit, which is the threshold.
—Then you add the second half.

—I will be coming to the second half in a moment. In the 1985 Budget the increase in TEAS kept pace with inflation and the increase in the threshold exceeded the rise in average weekly earnings. Senator Baume earlier complained that the disincentive, that is, the gap between TEAS and unemployment benefit, had not disappeared. I am sure he knows that it will progressively disappear under the new youth income arrangements. What he failed to mention, of course, is that the reason that that gap has not disappeared is that this Government has greatly increased unemployment benefits. That is why the gap has not gone.
—You promised you would close it.
—It will be closed.
—Some time in the future; in the never-never.
—No, it is laid down in the youth income scheme. Read the kit readily available from Senator Ryan's office.
—Senator Baume believes we should have kept unemployment benefits down.
—I think that is probably what it is, and remove the gap in that way.
—That is his policy.

—I agree. As one who was a student counsellor before entering the Parliament, I am very pleased to see the demise of this legislation. Even though it was never implemented, while it remained on the statute book it was a threat and fear in the minds of students. I wish it a very thankful goodbye.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —Of the two Bills before us I am happy to support the first, the Student Assistance Amendment Bill, because it gives flexibility to the Student Assistance Review Tribunals as well as to the Minister, and allows flexibility in respect of the period for following of any necessary prosecutions where a student may have breached the Act. So this Bill has gained support from all parts of the Senate. I used to act for the University of Adelaide students and others before such tribunals when they were first set up in 1974. I saw the first meeting, in fact, in South Australia of the tribunals. In those days-I think it is still the case-lawyers were unable to represent students so that a more informal and, if you like, a more commonsense and straightforward approach could be kept. It was in that guise that I was giving assistance to students. I believe these tribunals play an important and essential part in the administration of student allowances.

speech.para: I would only make the request of the Government that a standard be accepted by the Minister so that the period from the date of application to a tribunal to the time of the concluded finding being communicated to the student does not exceed three months. Given the informal and resourceful approach of these tribunals, I believe that is a very reasonable standard to meet. Even one or two months would, of course, be preferable. Students who believe that they should receive money under the tertiary education assistance scheme but whose application may be held up on a disputed technicality can suffer a delay that brings hardship and detracts from the success of their studies. I ask the Government to consider declaring itself to such a three-month standard.

I come to the second Bill that is currently before the Senate, that is, the Government's proposal to repeal the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Act 1982. The Opposition is opposed to this measure; it does not seek the repeal of this legislation, which we initiated in 1982. Whatever the arguments put, for example, by Senator Zakharov just now or by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in the second reading speech, there will always be fears, doubts and concerns in an area where there are grants and loans administered by the Commonwealth. I have not found anyone to deny that this scheme does provide the way to an extra benefit for students, and by repealing this legislation we are taking away one of the alternatives to give real assistance to students.

What did the original Bill seek to achieve? Its basis was that there would be no less support for TEAS; that all of the definitions of an individual allowance under the tertiary education assistance scheme would be undiminished; that there would be the same number or more of allowances; that there would be the same real value in the allowances; and there would be the same real value in the total Commonwealth commitment to the financing of the TEAS scheme. In addition to that, there would be a loans scheme that would then extend the financial resources available to students in our universities, colleges and institutes of technology, and indeed to technical and further education bodies. The Bill, as it was envisaged in 1982, made $50m available each and every year from then on. All full time students who were in financial need, subject to a means test, would be eligible to gain such a loan up to a maximum of $1,000 in any one year and up to an accrued maximum of $8,000 altogether. This loan would be administered on an objective eligibility basis. Students would not be denied on the basis of their future earning capacity, the type of course they would be doing, their sex, their age or anything to do with family background. It would be administered objectively and, above all, there would be a 5 per cent interest subsidy. If, as at that time, interest rates were prevailing at about 12 per cent, the interest payable on such loans would be only 7 per cent. There was an extended period of 15 years after graduation in which to repay those contracted loans.

In addition to there being the interest subsidy, the Commonwealth Government directly guaranteed to the Australian banks the outlay of moneys for such loans so that the banks were not in any way liable except to administer the scheme on the guidelines which the legislation provided. The Commonwealth would pick up any bad debts. Hence the Act was called the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Act. There was an element of guarantee from the Commonwealth Government and an element of subsidy of the rate of interest pay- able. That $50m a year benefit by now would have accrued $200m extra to students in Australia at a 5 per cent subsidised interest rate. I know that such a scheme would have enabled hundreds and thousands of students to take on their studies more satisfactorily. Indeed, it would have enabled many to conclude their tertiary education rather than have it foreshortened, suspended or compromised for lack of financial support. All students were seen to be eligible.

At the time the loans scheme was first proposed what seemed to be a major drawback was that the then Opposition and some students saw it-to use Senator Zakharov's words-as a possible thin end of the wedge to allow a loans scheme significantly to replace or even to replace any part of the tertiary education assistance scheme. That was why it was so fundamental for the Commonwealth Government at that time to make a cast iron commitment that there would be no diminishing of the tertiary education assistance scheme.

I happened to be the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts that investigated the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill. Debate on this Bill in the Senate was interrupted when this Bill was referred to the Senate Committee. Three Labor members and three Liberal members-four of whom are still in the Senate-investigated this Bill in very real detail. Banks, students and other interested bodies put views to us. As a result of that inquiry on the due date in November 1982 we came back to the Senate with a unanimous report. It was agreed to by both Labor and Liberal members of the Committee because the loans scheme was seen to be a genuine additional financial assistance resource for students. I, for one, had said months before in the Senate and in my own party room that I would go along only with a loans scheme that was supplementary to the grants schemes such as TEAS, post-graduate awards, Aboriginal study grants and other forms of direct financial assistance.

Another aspect, which was spelt out in the findings of the Senate Committee, was that there would be no compromising of the objective basis for eligibility for such loans. I quote directly from the second conclusion in the report, which states:

Apart from the eligibility provisions set out in the Bill which are to be administered by the Commonwealth Department of Education, the Agreement between the Government and the banks will restrict the banks to take into account only one criterion on which an eligible student's application for a loan can be denied: that is, a prior unsatisfactory repayment record already established by the applicant. Other factors such as future earning capacity, course of study, age, sex, academic record and socio-economic background will not be taken into account when banks are considering applications for loans.

This was the only other major area of wariness towards this scheme that had been expressed by the then Opposition. But it was spelt out categorically that there would be just one reason for denying any such loan to a full time student. Having given those two guarantees, the report went on to talk about assessing more carefully the total needs of students and matching the proposed $50m not to the capacity of the banks to provide money but to the needs of students. The report dealt with other matters that related to appeals, publicity, the eventual extension of the scheme to part time students and it recommended a periodic review. With those matters being so clearly spelt out, the unanimous report of that Senate Committee led to the Students (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill being passed, despite the antagonism that had been expressed earlier by the then Opposition and the Australian Democrats.

I have given a brief recall of the substance of the loans scheme proposal. I believe that it is still a sound proposal, that it would provide an additional financial resource and that this Bill ought to be on the statute books. I put to the Minister that it still ought to be possible to increase TEAS, as we did by increasing it by 20 per cent in our last Budget. The Government, in its three Budgets, increased it by 5 per cent, 10 per cent and 6.7 per cent. TEAS can be increased, as it has been in all of the last four years, but in addition there can be a more flexible financial resource for students through the provision of such a major loans scheme. It is therefore a sad day in the Senate when the Government proposes to deny one of the avenues that would make available a resource that students would use and would welcome.

I mention one matter which Senator Zakharov raised, I think, a little too optimistically. But, along the same lines, I support the concept she mentioned, and I always have supported it for years, even before the Bill was introduced in 1982. In addition to TEAS and the loan facility which is at risk with the withdrawal of the Act, I support the provision of an emergency campus-based loan fund for students in need. The Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, will recall my raising this proposal a number of times even in the last couple of years. I have urged that there be a provision of a reasonably small amount of money and that by giving it to the various institutions-universities, colleges of advanced education and institutes of technology-there would be a flexible facility, much more flexible than is presently the case, for helping students in need.

Senator Zakharov said that such schemes exist at the moment and that the present Government has made some provision for them. In 1973 a commitment was made by a Labor government. It was connected with the introduction of the tertiary education allowance scheme and the abolition of fees. The granting of that so-called maundy money in 1973 achieved successful results. I will not bore the Senate by repeating the success achieved. It is true that some of that money is still being recirculated, going from one student, back into the fund and then to another student, but in only a few institutions. Whilst small amounts may have been added, I wish to make a concrete proposal which I hope the Minister will receive in good faith, explore and implement.

If $14m were to be given to universities, colleges of advanced education, and institutes of technology, it could be distributed on a pro rata basis to equivalent full time students. It is estimated that there will be 280,000 equivalent full time students next year in our universities and CAEs. If that $14m were spread amongst these 64 institutions-the 19 universities and the 45 CAEs-5 per cent of all of those students could have available to them an average of $500 for an average loan period of two years. There could be various other combinations. One could vary the length of time for repayment or the amount of the loan.

Even small loans of $500 can make the difference between a student succeeding in a year of study, failing to pass half of his subjects, or, indeed, pulling out altogether. By providing $500 or $1,000 a very real facility could be given to students to help them complete such courses satisfactorily. Such a campus-based loan scheme should be given some guidelines. These guidelines can be spelt out in very brief terms, providing that the loans be reasonably short-term-less than three years-that they be administered entirely by persons within each campus and that the campus be responsible only for its own fund. I do not believe that there is even a need for subsequent accountability to the Commonwealth, as long as the loan scheme is administered on each campus to provide for those students most in need.

The essential element that would make for the success of such a scheme would be that these funds should not then be seen as being owned by the Government or by any establishment off campus. If they were seen to be given entirely to meet the needs of students, those students would have a very real incentive to repay such moneys so that they would help other students. Senator Zakharov referred to a fear experienced in the United States of America, the United Kingdom and some other countries. Particularly in the United States an attitude has developed amongst tertiary students that the loans ought not to be repaid or that there is no pressure or moral imperative to repay them because it is only money going back to the Government. I found, in administering a student loan fund, as part of my duties at the university of Adelaide, that repayment levels were extremely high-as high as 90 per cent. Loans were repaid punctually from moneys earned during vacation or in the course of the next calendar year. So loans can be undertaken over a 12-month or 24-month period with enormous benefit to students and they can be repaid because the students know that it is their money going back to them and that it will enable other students to be helped in the same way as they have been helped. I think such campus-based loans need not attract interest, except perhaps some fixed interest if there is a period of default. But, generally speaking, such loans should be interest free.

I put that summary view again to the Government and I ask: In all the millions of dollars that the Government is committing to education-even the increased $39m in this Budget under TEAS-could the Government not find $14m? We found $50m for a proposal that emerged from some of us when we were in government to make such a facility available to students. Can the Government not find even $14m to distribute amongst all the institutions? A few universities have reasonably well established loan funds but that is not the case in the majority of CAEs and the universities. The reason for my raising this matter in relation to this Bill is that at the time this legislation was debated in 1982, Senator Button, who was then as Leader of the Opposition the major Opposition speaker on this matter, said:
We would give much greater attention to loan schemes already administered by existing institutions, which could be vastly improved.

That was said by Senator Button in the Senate in his speech in the second reading debate on 13 October 1982. After the Bill had been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, of which I was a member, it came back to the Senate and was passed at the Government's initiative, with the support of the Australian Labor Party. Only the Australian Democrats were opposed to it. On 1 December 1982, as recorded at page 3002 of the Senate Hansard, Senator Button said:
In the second reading debate we also indicated that we should perhaps give further attention to existing loans schemes at tertiary institutions, particularly universities.

I do not concur with the rider at the end. I think that universities, CAEs, institutes of technology and tertiary and further education colleges should all be regarded alike and equitably. But this was the let-out, this was the rider that the then Labor Party senators added in their debate of this measure. Their reluctance to support it wholeheartedly-although they did with their vote-was as good as saying: `If we had the opportunity we would extend the loan schemes on the campuses'. I put it to Senator Zakharov, who has influence as a back bench member of the Government Party in the Senate, and I put it to the Minister that this is still a commitment which has not been met and which ought to be considered. I have outlined my suggestion in a concrete way. When this Bill was introduced in the Senate the Minister concluded her second reading speech in this way:
Furthermore, the Government has made a commitment not to proceed with the student loans scheme proposed by the Fraser Government. The present Bill fulfils that commitment.

I say to the Minister that when that commitment was made there was a second commitment. That second commitment was in the terms that I have read from Senator Button. That commitment was to establish campus-based emergency loan schemes so that they could operate as they were operating at that time in a few places very much to the benefit of students. I know that in principle the Minister supports such a scheme. Senator Button has never denied that commitment. I remind Government members that the Minister was referring not just to one commitment in her second reading speech but also to a second commitment. In the months ahead the Government has a chance to live up to that commitment as well.

I conclude by noting the progress that has been made with the tertiary education allowance scheme. As I indicated at the beginning of my speech, there have been some increases every year for the last four years. There was a massive increase of 20 per cent in the TEAS allowance in the last Liberal Budget in 1982. That 20 per cent increase was achieved in August 1982, immediately preceding the initiative for a loan scheme. So the 20 per cent increase was already in place when this legislation was originally debated in the Senate and when that loan initiative was seen to be supplementary to the TEAS scheme, including the 20 per cent increase.

I want honourable senators to recognise that, in the last three years of the Labor Government, there was an increase of 5 per cent in the TEAS allowance in the first Labor Budget which was to operate for 1984, a 10 per cent increase in the second Labor Budget which was to operate for 1985 and a 6.7 per cent increase in the recent August Budget which is to operate for 1986. That nearly keeps pace with inflation. It is a reasonably commendable effort but it is an effort which does not live up to the Government's profession. It promised students that it would vastly increase support for student assistance and that is why so many students have been let down and are disappointed by these increases in the TEAS allowance. From December 1981 to December 1982 the inflation rate in Australia was 10.9 per cent. Having regard to that, the former Liberal Government gave TEAS a 20 per cent increase. In the August 1983 Budget this Government gave a 5 per cent increase, which is relative to the December 1982 to December 1983 inflation rate of 8.7 per cent. The family income on which the maximum TEAS allowance is determined was also increased in that year by 6 per cent. For the 1985 year, the August 1984 Budget gave the 10 per cent increase not only to TEAS but also to the family income means test, when the inflation rate was about only half of that figure.

So, whilst there has been no particular rhyme or reason to the increase in the TEAS allowance relative to the inflation rate, it has roughly or nearly kept pace with inflation. In this last year the inflation rate was 6.7 per cent and the increase in the TEAS allowance was 6.7 per cent, so in those terms we have had some commendable achievements by both Liberal and Labor governments. However, as my colleague Senator Peter Baume has already outlined, relative to the unemployment benefit the full TEAS allowance for 1986 is to be $73.28 whereas the unemployment benefit for 18- to 20-year-olds is $88.20-a gap of about $1.15-or $91.45 for 21-year-olds and above without dependants, which is approximately an $18 gap. That gap of $15 or $18 between the TEAS allowance and the unemployment benefit has grown during the period of the Labour Government by some $10 or $12.

Whilst Government members will be quick to say that the reason for that gap has been the increase in the unemployment benefit and a lesser increase in the TEAS allowance, the gap is nevertheless there. It is a real gap and the Government has not lived up to its earlier commitment to see that gap bridged. I remind the Senate that the Liberal Party, prior to the last Federal election, gave the commitment that we would close the gap between the TEAS allowance and the unemployment benefit as the first step in eliminating the perverse incentives which currently exist for unemployment rather than tertiary education. While maintaining the unemployment benefit, we will progressively increase the TEAS allowance. It goes without saying that we urge the Government in implementing that policy to make further progress towards bridging the gap in any opportunities the Government has in the months ahead.
In conclusion, the Opposition is opposed to this legislation because it wishes to see the widest possible range of resources for student assistance.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: —in reply-In closing the second reading debate I will confine my remarks to those made on the two Bills under consideration by the Senate. The debate has ranged far and wide and honourable senators from the other side have taken the opportunity to give their views on a number of matters related to youth income support and student income support generally but not specifically to the Bills in question. The two Bills that the Senate has been debating are the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Repeal Bill and the Student Assistance Amendment Bill. Our Government announced very early upon its election in 1983 that it would repeal the first Bill, that it would not proceed with that scheme. I do not think it is necessary to rehearse yet again the reasons for that decision.
—There aren't any.

—The reasons are on record. That scheme of student assistance would assist those students whose families were able to guarantee them for a loan-students who were able to be assured because of their family circumstances or because of the kind of course they were undertaking that they would be able to repay that loan. Such students would be advantaged whereas students from poor families or students who intended to pursue a career in a not very remunerative area would be discriminated against by the scheme. I do not think there is any reason to proceed to explain why this discriminatory and inequitable proposal for student assistance was rejected by our Government from the very earliest days. It has taken some time, because of the proceedings of the Senate, for us actually to repeal formally this Bill but we were quite clear on coming to office that we would not proceed with this discriminatory form of student assistance, and we have not done so.

speech.para: There is no need to say any more about it except that Senator Teague did speak at some length about the need for a special student assistance loans scheme. It is unfortunate that Senator Teague has not acquainted himself with the initiatives that the Government has taken in that direction. We have in fact built upon the existing Beazley emergency loans schemes which, as Senator Teague is aware, operated in only some universities and not in colleges of advanced education. We have now instituted a new loans scheme which is funded by the redistribution of funds away from the non-needs based per capita funding of student residences in those institutions which are fortunate enough to have them and which benefited only those students who were fortunate enough to be in them, giving no benefit whatsoever to students whose institutions had no such accommodation or who could never afford or get a place in such accommodation.

That scheme was inequitable and discriminatory. We have changed it; we have redistributed the funds available under that scheme on a phased basis. Senator Teague will be interested to know that $10m has been allocated over the triennium for emergency loans schemes, which will operate on every higher education campus in Australia, which will operate under guidelines which require student participation in their management, and the management of which, I believe, will be as democratic and successful as was the management of the Beazley emergency loans funds. Of course, we would like to supplement the amounts in those schemes but certainly the kinds of schemes that Senator Teague was suggesting in his proposal are already under way; the reports that I have had from various campuses and from students are that they are operating quite well. As in all such cases, they could do with some extra money but certainly there is a fairer and better targeted use of funds than there was under the previous scheme of per capita assistance to students in residences and nothing for anybody else.

If Senator Teague were to address himself to that he would find that some of the suggestions he has made this evening are really being met and will be successively met as funds become available. We never intended to proceed with the loans scheme. We made that clear from our days in opposition. On coming to government we made it quite clear that that scheme would not operate and it has not done so. As Senator Teague very frankly and generously has acknowledged, there have been increases in the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance. Again, we would all wish to see those increases continue and be greater but that is a matter for budgetary consideration.

I also point out to Senator Teague that the objective of reducing the gap between the unemployment benefit and education allowances is being pursued. In the Priority One youth assistance scheme announced by the Government at Budget time there is a period during which the gap between the unemployment benefit and the relevant education allowance will be closed. They will not all be closed immediately but over a period. That gap, which Senator Teague, Senator Zakharov, Senator McIntosh and I all agree is a disincentive for students from poorer families to continue their education, will be addressed-not as speedily as we would all wish in an ideal world, but that process has started. I am pleased to say that the fact that we have started this and have a long term plan to reduce those disincentives for poorer students to continue their studies has been generally welcomed throughout the education community.

We are really making four amendments to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill. We are restructuring the present system of the Student Assistance Review Tribunals. We are taking steps to protect confidential documents during hearings and not provide protection at the pre-hearing stage only. We are enabling some ministerial responsibilities to be delegated to senior departmental officers, which Senator Peter Baume knows is a method of streamlining the processing of applications. We are also extending the time limit for bringing prosecutions from one to two years.

Senator Haines asked a number of questions in relation to those matters. As she is not in the chamber now and may not be present at the Committee stage, I will take this opportunity to answer her questions and I am sure that all honourable senators will be interested in the answers. Senator Haines asked why students should not have access to departmental briefing notes in an appeal situation. The response to this question is that such notes are not departmental documents, they are internal working documents produced by the Tribunal secretary for the Tribunal. They are not made available to the students nor to the departmental officers, so it would be inappropriate for a student to have access to them.

Senator Haines also wanted to know why we have extended the prosecution period from one to two years. The reason for this is a practical one. It has proven difficult to detect, investigate and commence legal action within the existing time limit of one year particularly when enrolment checks and so on are conducted sometimes months after the offence is committed. Further, the mobile nature of the student population makes these kinds of investigations difficult. However, I would point out to honourable senators that the two year period proposed compares favourably with the three years under the Social Security Act.

Senator Haines also requested a clarification of what the intention is in the protection of documents in clause 29B. The existing provision covers only documents at the pre-hearing stage. The new provision extends the protection from the pre-hearing stage to the hearing stage and also extends protection to oral disclosure of documents and contents. Finally, it allows disclosure of a person's personal affairs with their consent. The proposed amendment would in no way reduce a student's ability to pursue effectively his or her appeal. I think that that is a very important principle and one that I think Senator Haines will be very pleased to have confirmed.

We were further asked why there are delays in appeal hearings. Extended delays are unusual and quite an exception. Most appeals are heard within three months. It is worth reminding honourable senators here this evening that some delays are experienced in arranging suitable times for Tribunal members. The delays in SART hearings compare favourably with other external tribunals, for example the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I am pleased to report to the Senate that the number of outstanding appeals at the moment is half what it was at this time last year. So certainly in terms of streamlining and speeding up the appeals procedure I think we are making progress and I expect that the provisions in the Bill we are currently debating will enable further progress to be made which I am sure will be made to the satisfaction of all honourable senators. I commend both Bills to the Senate.
